summary: This 1930 West African Court of Appeal decision involved an interpleader application by Chief Kweku Danso, who opposed a writ of possession granted to Chief Kuturka Yardom following a prior land boundary judgment. Chief Danso claimed occupation of land included in the writ and sought protection under Order XLV Rule 5 of the Rules of the Supreme Court. The lower court registered his application as a suit and stayed execution. The appellate court reversed, holding that Danso had not been dispossessed and thus his application was premature under Rule 5, which requires actual dispossession. The appeal was allowed, costs were reduced, and the lower court was directed to proceed accordingly.
citations: Order XLV Rule 5, Rules of Supreme Court, Schedule II
Hayes Redwar, Comments on Gold Coast Ordinances
rationaleHighlights: Applicant must be dispossessed to invoke Order XLV Rule 5
Application was premature as no dispossession occurred
Court below lacked jurisdiction to register suit
No cause of action disclosed in ex parte papers
Marginal note 'Interpleader' informs interpretation of Rule 5
Appeal should have been taken earlier from March 28 order
confidenceNotes: High confidence; details are clearly drawn from the original judgment text, with precise procedural and jurisdictional context from the Gold Coast era. Citation of rules and commentary supports accuracy.
